column1: The Doshisha Corporation (The Doshisha) is the educational corporation to which Doshisha University and Doshisha Women's College belong.

Doshisha was founded in 1875 by Joseph Hardy Neesima as a Christian Protestant (Congregational) school based on Christian principles, and is a comprehensive educational institution with nine educational facilities bearing the name "Doshisha" from university to kindergarten (as of April 2005).
As of April 2004, approximately 36,000 people are studying at Doshisha University.
Currently, Doshisha Educational Corporation has obtained an <AA+> rating from Rating and Investment Information, Inc. (R&I).
<AA+> is the second highest rating out of 21 levels.
Waseda University and Keio University are among the top school corporations.
The founding spirit of Doshisha University is "conscience" based on the Christian spirit.
Shinshiro Toshimasa advocated for the cultivation of individuals who "utilize their conscience in their actions" as the purpose of education.
It is desired to produce people who are "filled with conscience" by promoting "moral education" based on Christianity in parallel with education that does not lean towards knowledge education.
Monuments engraved with his handwriting expressing those thoughts can be found at various schools such as Doshisha University.
The words "May the whole body of this conscience monument be filled with a robust spirit" are engraved on this conscience monument.

Furthermore, in order to concretely realize this "conscience" education, the educational principles of "Christianity," "liberalism," and "internationalism" are advocated, aiming to produce individuals who embody the "conscience of a nation" through these principles.
It is a Protestant Christian school corporation that follows the tradition of the Congregationalist Church (United Church of Christ).
However, it is different in nature from so-called mission-based universities and does not have the primary purpose of Christian evangelism (it does not use education itself as a means of evangelism).
A school corporation founded in 1875 by one of the six great educators of the Meiji era, Jo Niijima, with Doshisha English School as its predecessor.
In 1875, J.C. Hepburn founded Doshisha English School in Marutamachi, Teramachi, Kyoto.
In 1876, it moved from Teramachi to Imadegawa.
In April 1877, the Doshisha branch school for women was established, and in September it was renamed Doshisha Women's School.
Establishment of the Doshisha University Regulations in 1883.
In 1888, the "Purpose of Establishing Doshisha University" was announced in major newspapers and magazines nationwide.
In 1896, the ordinary school was renamed Doshisha High School.
Established the Doshisha Junior High School.
In 1897, M.F. Denton opened the Demachi Kindergarten.
In 1900, Shutchou Kindergarten was renamed to Imadegawa Kindergarten.
In 1904, theological schools and vocational schools were established under the Vocational School Order.

In 1912, Doshisha University (preparatory school, theology department, political economy department, English department) and Women's School Specialized Department (English department, home economics department) were established under the Vocational School Law.
Doshisha University was founded in 1920 under the University Ordinance.
Ikkyu Sojun was a Zen monk of the Rinzai sect of the Rinzai sect of the Muromachi period.
Known as a model of speech.

Regarding "Ikkyu-san no Tonchi-banashi," please refer to the section on "Ikkyu-ban" (there is also some description on this page). For the TV anime "Ikkyu-san," please refer to the section on "Ikkyu-san."
Born in Kyoto, said to be a descendant of Emperor Go-Komatsu.

In the diary of Sugawara Nagamasa, "Diary of Tohojo Nagamasa" in the third year of Meio (1494), it is written on the first day of August: "It is said in secret that Ikkyu Sojun is the illegitimate imperial son of Gosho-in."
"There is no one in the world who knows it."
According to later historical records, his childhood name was Chigikumaru.
He was later called Zhou Jian, and went by the aliases of Kuang Yunzi, Xialu, and Mukei.
The posthumous Buddhist name is Shu Jun, also written as Shu Jun.
Ikkyu is a Buddhist monk's title.
Please refer to the "posthumous Buddhist name" section for information on posthumous Buddhist names and temple names.
At the age of 6, he entered the Ankokuzan Hōkō-ji in Kyoto and received the precepts, and was named Shūken.

From an early age, he excelled in poetry, and his Chinese poems "Changmen Spring Grass" written at the age of 13 and "Spring Clothes Lodging Flowers" written at the age of 15 became well-known and praised in the capital city of Luoyang.
In the 17th year of Oei (1410), at the age of 17, he became a disciple of Ken'o Sui and changed his name to Soshun.
At this time, it cannot be determined whether Ikkyu's behavior is due to his master's passing, but he has attempted suicide.
In the 22nd year of Oei (1415), he became a disciple of Kaso Sodon, a high priest of Daikakuji Temple in Kyoto.

He received the nickname "Ikkyu" from Hoso, because he answered the koan "The stick of Dongshan" with the verse: "From existence to non-existence, take a break. When it rains, let it rain. When the wind blows, let it blow."
"Arroji (world of defilements)" refers to the world of delusion (afflictions), while "muroji (world of enlightenment)" refers to the world of enlightenment (Buddha).
One night in the 27th year of Oei (1420), upon hearing the cawing of a crow, I suddenly had a great realization.
The old man tried to give Ikkyu a written permission, but Ikkyu declined.
It is said that the old man sent him off laughing as a fool.
Afterwards, I lived a life of poetry, mad songs, calligraphy, and eccentricity.
In the first year of Shōchō (1428), Emperor Shōkō passed away without leaving a male heir, and Emperor Go-Hanazono was welcomed from the Fushimi-no-miya family and ascended to the throne.
It is said that Ikkyu recommended the enthronement of Emperor Go-Hanazono.
From "The Biography of Ikkyu Sojun in the Tokai Region".
However, Imaizumi Yoshio argues that the enthronement of Go-Hanazono was approved by the shogunate and was not related to Ikkyu's recommendation.

In the 6th year of the Bunmei era following the Ōnin War (1474), he was appointed as the head priest of Daitoku-ji by the decree of Emperor Go-Tsuchimikado, the 47th head priest. Though he did not reside in the temple, he made great efforts in its restoration.
The Kyoto Imperial Palace (Kyoto Gosho) is the imperial residence located in Kamigyo-ku, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Due to the Tokyo visit of the Meiji Restoration, the Emperor moved to the Imperial Palace in Tokyo (formerly Edo Castle), and it was preserved in the 10th year of Meiji (1877).
After the Meiji era, it was also known as the Kyoto Imperial Palace.
Originally, the official Imperial Palace in Heian-kyo was located in the central part of Heian-kyo, but it was moved to the Rikyu Palace due to damage caused by wars and other factors.
The Togu Palace of the Daitokuji Temple was one of the palaces in this village, where the imperial family of the Jomyo-in line, later known as the Northern Court, resided.
By the way, the imperial palace of the Daikakuji line, which would later be called the Southern Court, was located in the Nijo Tomikoji Palace.
The modern Kyoto Imperial Palace is not the same as the original Doigomon Higashidoin Palace, but rather an expansion based on the Doigomon Higashidoin Palace.
Usually, you can visit by applying, and it is open to the public in spring and autumn.
The Kyoto Imperial Palace was the residence and office of successive emperors until the Imperial Court moved to Tokyo in the second year of the Meiji era (1869).
The Kyoto Imperial Palace in the present day (21st century) is state-owned property classified as "Imperial Household Property" under the jurisdiction of the Imperial Household Agency.

Adjacent to Kyoto Imperial Palace and Sentō Imperial Palace, and across the street to the north on Imadegawa Street are Doshisha University and Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts (both campuses are located on Imadegawa Street).

Currently, the Imperial Household Agency manages the Kyoto Imperial Palace, Kyoto Sento Imperial Palace, and the Sento Imperial Palace, while the Ministry of the Environment manages the Kyoto Gyoen National Garden surrounding them.
Kyoto residents often simply refer to the Kyoto Imperial Palace as "Gosho," including the Kyoto Imperial Garden.

However, unlike castles in foreign countries, the walls surrounding the Imperial Palace are not very high. There is a theory that this difference reflects the sense of closeness between the common people and the rulers (such as the Emperor and the imperial family) in the East and the West.

For example, during the French Revolution, there was an incident where commoners invaded the Palace of Versailles, which was the residence of the ruler (king). The fact that such incidents have not occurred in Japan is one of the bases for this analysis.

The original Imperial Palace of Heian-kyo was located considerably to the west of the current Kyoto Imperial Palace, near the Nijo Station of West Japan Railway, at the northeast corner of the Senbon Marutamachi intersection.

The current Kyoto Imperial Palace was originally one of the residences of the retired Emperor, called the Tsuchimikado Higashidoin, and was first used by Emperor Kogon of the Northern Court in the first year of the Genko era (1331).

The Imperial Palace that was here was rebuilt eight times only during the Edo period (six of which were rebuilt due to fires), and the existing building was rebuilt in the late Edo period in the second year of Ansei (1855) in the Heian style, and is called the Ansei Imperial Palace.

In the 10th year of Meiji (1877), Emperor Meiji, who had moved to the Imperial Palace in Tokyo, visited Kyoto and lamented the deteriorating condition of the Kyoto Imperial Palace within 10 years of his visit to Tokyo. He ordered for the preservation of the palace and the maintenance of its old appearance.
Main buildings include the Shishinden, Seiryoden, Kogosho, Ogakumonjo, Tsunegoten, Koushun, Osuzumisho, and Empress's Palace.

The enthronement ceremony has been traditionally held at the Shishin-den Hall in the Kyoto Imperial Palace for generations. Even after the Emperor moved to Tokyo during the Meiji Restoration, according to the old Imperial Household Law established in 1889 (Meiji 22), it was stipulated that the enthronement ceremony and the Daijosai ceremony should be held in Kyoto. Both Emperor Taisho and Emperor Showa also performed their enthronement ceremonies at the Kyoto Imperial Palace.

In addition, there is no specific provision in the current Imperial Household Law established after World War II that the enthronement ceremony must be held in Kyoto. In 1990, for the enthronement of the current Emperor, the enthronement ceremony was held for the first time in history at the Imperial Palace in Tokyo.

During the enthronement ceremony, the Emperor sits on the Takamikura, the official throne of the Emperor symbolizing the enthronement, which is located in the Shishin-den Hall of the Kyoto Imperial Palace. Therefore, for the current Emperor's enthronement ceremony, known as the "Sokuiden no Gi" (equivalent to the "Shishin-den no Gi"), the Takamikura was temporarily moved to the Imperial Palace.

The gate is only opened for special events such as the visit of the Emperor, dignitaries, and foreign guests, as well as for public viewing.
The left and right Tsuijibei walls have five lines (horizontal lines) running through them, which also indicate the highest level of formality as a wall.

Gagaku is one of the traditional music of Japan, China, the Korean Peninsula, and Vietnam.
The following will focus on Japanese gagaku transmitted to the Imperial Household Agency's Music Department (Important Intangible Cultural Property).
The original meaning of gagaku is "elegant and correct music and dance," contrasting with "popular music."

According to the definition by the Imperial Household Agency Shikibu-shoku Gakubu, it refers to the repertoire performed by the Imperial Household Agency Shikibu-shoku Gakubu, excluding Western music.
Many of them have been inherited as court music in instrumental music.
It is the oldest style of traditional music in the world that is still performed in large ensemble form today.

However, as a form of ensemble music in its original form, it had been discontinued for over 100 years since the Onin War until the Tokugawa shogunate gathered the descendants of musicians (gakka) and reorganized it, so it is questionable how much of the Heian period form has been inherited.

When singing the musical notation written in katakana for the hichiriki, it is speculated that the pronunciation of the Ha row is pronounced as fa, fi, fu, fe, fo, and other features of the pronunciation of Japanese before the 16th century are faithfully reproduced, making it quite faithful overall.

Things written in kanji, like the notation of the Raku biwa, have many similarities with the biwa notation found in Dunhuang, China, and many styles that were passed down from an even older continent are also inherited.
One of the most important historical sources is the "Taigen Shō" written by Toyohara Tsunemasa (1450-1512), who was concerned about the dispersal of records such as gagaku due to the Ōnin War.
Tsukiai, the head of the Shakuhachi music family, compiled records on Gagaku and Bugaku centered around the Shakuhachi. It is a valuable record of ancient Gagaku.
The music for rituals that originated from China, the Korean Peninsula, and South Asia before the 10th century.
In China, ya-yüe was music performed at ceremonies.

However, among the pieces currently performed in Japanese gagaku, Tang music, which is said to have been transmitted from China, is said to be based on the music played at a banquet called Yan music in the Tang dynasty.

In terms of music categories, names with international colors such as Tang music, Goryeo music, and Linyi music (music of Champa) are transmitted, and elements of ancient Japanese music from before the arrival of continental music are also included.

Before modern times, the Tennoji Gakuso at Shitennoji Temple (Osaka), the Dainai Gakuso at the Imperial Palace (Kyoto), and the Nanto Gakuso at Kasuga Taisha Shrine (Nara) were considered the three major Gakuso institutions that preserved the oldest styles.

These music schools were called to Tokyo in modern times, forming the foundation of the current Imperial Household Agency's music department, but the traditions of each music school continue in their respective regions.
In addition, mutual influences can be seen between folk songs and statements, and Japan's unique style has been created.
Currently, about 100 songs have been inherited by the Imperial Household Agency's Music Department.
Refer to the lyrics of the S-style song and dance.
There is a view that only things that have come from outside Japan are considered as gagaku.
Left dance and Tang music... Chinese, Indian, and Lin Yi (Southern Vietnam) origin
Right dance, Goryeo music... Korean, Bohai (Northeast China) origin
These include songs produced in Japan that imitate the above-mentioned style (Japanese music).

There are cases where ancient songs and dances in the national style are collectively referred to as ancient songs and dances.
Emperor Kanmu (737-806) was the 50th emperor of Japan.
Emperor Kanmu was born as the first son of Prince Shirakabe (later Emperor Kōnin) in the 9th year of Tenpyō (737).
According to the Nihon Shoki, Takano Shinkasa, the mother, is said to be a descendant of the Baekje royal family, descended from King Munju of Baekje.
Empress Fujiwara no Otomuro gave birth to Prince Yasukado (later Emperor Heijō), and Empress Fujiwara no Tabiko gave birth to Prince Ōtomo (later Emperor Junna).

Even after his father, King Hakoku, ascended to the throne, Prince Shotoku was not desired to be the crown prince because his mother, Koyasan Shinkasa, came from the low-ranking immigrant clan of the Wa clan. Initially, he aimed for career advancement as a bureaucrat, serving as a chamberlain, head of the university, and minister of the center.

However, due to political disputes involving the Fujiwara clan, the former Crown Prince and his mother, Empress Inoue, were suddenly deposed and the younger half-brother was proclaimed Crown Prince on January 2, 773.
In order to avoid the growing influence of the Nara Buddhist temples in Heijokyo, the capital was moved to Yamashiro Province.
In 784, Nagaoka-kyo was built, but in 794, Heian-kyo was built again.
In order to invade the Tohoku region and subjugate the Emishi, a military force was sent with Sakanoue no Tamuramaro as the commander-in-chief.
However, in his later years, he was criticized by Fujiwara no Yoshitsugu of the Fujiwara Shikike family for causing suffering to the peasants with such military and construction activities.
It is said that he proposed the compilation of the Nihon Shoki in terms of culture.
Saicho and Kukai returned from Tang China and brought new developments to Japanese Buddhism under the rule of Emperor Kanmu.

The unnatural deaths of Princess Inoue and Prince Tamura, as well as the dark side of exiling and causing the death of Prince Hayara, who was made Crown Prince at the beginning of his reign, on charges of assassinating Fujiwara Shigenobu in 785.

Out of fear of vengeful spirits, on July 19, 800, Emperor Kanmu posthumously honored Prince Sawara as Emperor Sudo, designated Princess Inoue's tomb as a mausoleum, and restored the position of Empress.

Known as the protectors of Saicho and Kukai, while existing Buddhism had too much power involved in the government, they put pressure on various sects known as the "Nanto Rokushu" by confiscating their land and other oppressive measures.
It is also said that the disorder in the imperial harem led to the later "Incident at Yaxie".
He passed away on March 17, 806, in the 25th year of the Enryaku era.
Emperor Jimmu, who was posthumously known as Yamato Takeru no Mikoto, was the founder of Japan.
Along with this, Emperor Kanmu was posthumously given the Chinese-style posthumous title.
Kashiwabara Emperor, also known as Tenkoku Oshihara Miya Kashiwabara Tenno.
The tomb is said to be the Kashiwabara Mausoleum (Kashiwabara no Misasagi) in Momoyama-cho, Fushimi-ku, Kyoto City.
Before his death, he was insistent on being buried in Utono, but due to various reasons, he was buried in Fushimi's Kashiwabara Mausoleum.
In the Meiji era, the first emperor of Heian-kyo was enshrined at the Heian Shrine.
All emperors are enshrined in one of the three Imperial Mausoleums at the Imperial Palace.

On December 18, 2001, before the Emperor's birthday, at the customary press conference, Akihito made a statement regarding the co-hosting of the FIFA World Cup the following year, saying, "I feel a connection with the Republic of Korea as it is recorded in the Nihon Shoki that the mother of Emperor Kanmu was a descendant of King Munmu of Baekje."
This statement was not widely covered in Japan, but it was widely reported in the South Korean media and became a topic of discussion.
Some media outlets have made significant leaps in logic, such as claiming that the Imperial Family has Korean ancestry, based on theories like the "Imperial Family Baekje Origin Theory."
The Otani family (Otanike) is the family name of the descendants of Kakuei, the son of Kakushin-ni and Hino Hirotuna.
Hino Hiroyuki was a lower-ranking noble in Kyoto, and Kakushin-ni was the daughter of Shinran who inherited the position of head priest of Hongan-ji, the majority sect of Jodo Shinshu.

When surnames became mandatory during the Meiji era, both the head priests of the Jodo Shinshu Honganji sect (Nishi Honganji) and the head priests of the Shinshu Otani sect (Shinshu Honbyo) that split in 1602 took on surnames.
The origin of the Otani surname is due to the fact that the mausoleum of Shinran, mentioned later, was established in the Otani area north of the main gate of Chion-in Temple in Higashiyama, Kyoto.

Hongan-ji was considered one of the daimyo (feudal lords) during the Sengoku period in Japan, as it had power comparable to other daimyo due to the spread of the Ikko Ikki movement. It is common to refer to the head priest with the temple's name, such as "Hongan-ji Kennyo" or "Hongan-ji Kosa," but this is simply for convenience and does not mean that the head priest's family lineage made Hongan-ji their surname. There was no family name or clan known as Hongan-ji.
Kakushin-ni watched over Shinran's death in 1262 and built a hall to enshrine his remains in Otani near his home in Higashiyama, Kyoto in 1272.
Daibutsu-do became a place of worship for Jodo Shinshu followers as a mausoleum for Shinran, and Shinran's eldest son Kakuei was appointed as the caretaker to manage it in his absence.

However, the Otani mausoleum later became a source of conflict between the son of Kakuei, Kakunyo, and his half-brother, Yosazen, as they competed for control over the temple's administration and donations from followers of various provinces. Kakunyo narrowly emerged victorious and established the hereditary succession of the temple's administration within his own family.
In 1312, Kakunyo converted the mausoleum into a temple, giving birth to the Jodo Shinshu sect.

Since then, the descendants of Kakunyo inherited the Honganji Temple and advanced the formation of the sect. By the time of the 5th generation Jakkunyo in the Muromachi period, the Honganji sect had expanded to the Hokuriku region, and by the time of the 7th generation Sonnyo, the Honganji sect had been formed in Kaga, Noto, Echizen, Omi, and other provinces.

However, compared to other lineages of Jodo Shinshu that have been working on forming a religious organization since the death of Shinran, the formation of the organization was significantly delayed. In the early Muromachi period, Honganji was considered a sub-temple of Seiren-in, and it is said that the Otani family, through their connection to the Hino family (Shinran's family), also served as stewards for the Kujo family.

In the latter half of the 15th century, due to the activities of Rennyo, who became the 8th head priest, the Honganji sect spread throughout Japan. However, in 1465, the main Honganji temple was destroyed and the head priest moved to Yoshizaki in Echizen, and then to the Yamashina district on the outskirts of Kyoto.

In Kaga, against the backdrop of the expansion of the teachings during the time of Rennyo, the Kaga Ikko Ikki occurred in 1488, leading to the expulsion of the guardian Tomogashi family by the Honganji sect in Kaga, resulting in the emergence of a situation known as the "country ruled by peasants."
For approximately one hundred years until 1580, it became a country ruled by the Ikko sect.

In the 16th century, amidst the chaos of the Warring States period, the Honganji sect, starting from small farmers, utilized its organizational strength to expand its activities throughout Japan, reaching the warrior class such as samurai and local lords. However, the Yamashina Honganji temple suffered from the Tenbun Hokke Disturbance in 1532, and the 10th head, Shonyo, relocated to the Ishiyama Gobo founded by Rennyo in Nishinaru-gun, Settsu Province (present-day Osaka City), renaming it Ishiyama Honganji.
Ishiyama Hongan-ji was located on the top of a hill at the northern end of the Kamimachi Plateau.
The key point of river transportation at the mouth of the Yodogawa River was controlled by Osaka.
Based in Ishiyama Hongan-ji, Shonin sought to strengthen ties with various daimyo, the shogunate, and the imperial court, stabilizing the power base of Hongan-ji.

On the other hand, from the end of the Jisho era, in regions such as Hokuriku, some members of the local Honganji sect were beginning to deviate from the control of Honganji and follow their own path.

During the time of the 11th head priest, Kenju, of the Jodo Shinshu sect, the Honganji sect had effectively become an independent daimyo power. They expanded into the Kinai region and came into conflict with Oda Nobunaga, who sought to establish unified control by taking away lordship power from religious forces.

The conflict between the Honganji Temple and the Oda clan, which lasted for ten years from 1570, known as the Ishiyama War, saw the Honganji Temple, fortified at Ishiyama, collaborate with followers resisting the Oda clan in various regions, gaining the upper hand and causing great difficulties for Nobunaga.

However, in 1574, Ganjoji Temple in Nagashima-cho, Ise Province (Mie Prefecture) was destroyed by the Oda clan, and in 1575, the uprising that recaptured Echizen from the Oda clan was annihilated, weakening resistance in various regions. In 1578, the Mori clan's navy, allied with Honganji Temple, was defeated by the Oda navy in the Battle of Kizu River, marking another defeat outside of Honganji Temple.

While maintaining its strength by gathering support from the Iga clan and others, Hongan-ji gradually became isolated among its enemies. In 1580, it finally succumbed to Nobunaga, who obtained an imperial decree from Emperor Ogimachi, and retreated from Ishiyama Hongan-ji. The power of Hongan-ji as a feudal lord disappeared.

At this time, the eldest son Kyonyo and Kenyo, who advocated continuing to resist against Kenyo's intentions, had a falling out. When Kenyo passed away in 1593, his third son Junyo was appointed as his successor.

From this point on, Hongan-ji began to walk the path of division over the position of the head priest, and in 1602 Tokugawa Ieyasu granted a separate temple ground to Kyonyo, apart from Kyonyo's Hongan-ji sect, establishing the East Hongan-ji.

At this time, many followers from the Jodo sect led by Junjo, who became the head of Nishi Honganji, moved to the guidance of Kyonyo, the head of Higashi Honganji, and Honganji split into two factions.

Shinran, originally the son of Hino Arinori, a court noble, and the head of the Eastern and Western Tani families, who descended from Hino Hirotsun (the father of Kakunyo), had a tradition of becoming adopted sons of powerful court nobles, and also continued to intermarry with court nobles for generations, leading to the advancement of their status through the maternal line.
Kyotanabe City is located near the border of Osaka Prefecture and Nara Prefecture in the southern part of Kyoto Prefecture.

Kyo-tanabe City is located in the central part of the triangular area of the three prefectures, in the southern part of Kyoto Prefecture, adjacent to Yawata City, Joyo City, Ikoma Town in Tsuzuki District, Seika Town in Sagara District, Hirakata City in Osaka Prefecture, and Ikoma City in Nara Prefecture.

The Kizugawa River flows north and south along the eastern side of the city (Kyoto Prefecture), while the western side is sandwiched between the Ikoma Mountains, with the central area being crossed by the West Japan Railway Company's Katamachi Line and the Kintetsu Kyoto Line.
Kyoto City, Nara City, and Osaka City have a strong character as bedroom communities.

This corresponds to the area east of the Sumida River in the current Saitama Prefecture and Tokyo, excluding islands, as well as the northeastern part of Kanagawa Prefecture (including all of Kawasaki City and the eastern and coastal areas of Yokohama City).

Heian-kyo was established as the capital of Japan by Emperor Kammu in the year 794 (Enryaku 13).

Heian-kyo was built in the area that now corresponds to the central part of Kyoto City, spanning the Katsura District and the Atago District in Yamashiro Province. It was a capital city that was laid out in a rectangular shape measuring 4.5km east to west and 5.2km north to south.

Establishing the Imperial Palace at the northern center of the capital, and from there, placing the Suzaku Avenue through the center of the city, with the left side being the Left Capital and the right side being the Right Capital (the east side is the Left Capital, and the west side is the Right Capital).
The layout plan is basically based on Heijokyo, following the example of Chang'an in the Sui and Tang dynasties.
However, there were no city walls.
There is a theory that the selection of this land was based on the Four Gods corresponding to Feng Shui, which was transmitted from China.
The area of Heian-kyo is smaller than the current Kyoto city.
The northernmost main road is Ichijo Street, located between Imadegawa Street and Marutamachi Street.
The southern limit of Kujo Oji is Kujo Street slightly south of the current JR Kyoto Station.

Emperor Kanmu moved the capital to Yamashiro Province in 784 and built the city of Nagaoka-kyo.

It is said that there was an intention to move away from the powerful nobles and temples that supported the government of the Emperor Tenmu lineage in Yamato Province, and to establish a new capital for the Emperor Tenchi lineage.
However, just 10 years later in 794, Emperor Kammu relocated the capital to the northern part of Yamashiro Province, and Heian-kyo was established.

It is believed that this relocation of the capital was influenced by a series of incidents from the assassination of Fujiwara Tanezane in Nagaoka-kyo to the abdication of Prince Sawara, as well as the slow progress of the construction of Nagaoka-kyo.
It is believed that the construction of Heian-kyo began with the building of the Imperial Palace (Daijokyu) and then proceeded to the construction of the city (urban area).
However, due to the fact that the area of Ukyo is a wetland formed by the Katsura River (part of the Yodo River system), urbanization did not progress even into the 9th century.
In the 10th century, when the Ritsuryo system had largely become obsolete, there were cases of land being converted to agricultural use, which was originally prohibited within the capital.
The residential area for the nobility was established in the left capital, excluding the northern part of the right capital near the Imperial Palace.
The Nihon Koki is an official history book compiled in the early Heian period, and is the third of the six national histories following the Nihon Shoki.
Completed in the 7th year of Jōwa (840), it covers a period of 42 years from the 11th year of Enryaku (792) to the 10th year of Tenchō (833).
The editor is Fujiwara no Tsugutsugu and others.
According to the preface, in the 10th year of Konin (819), Emperor Saga ordered Fujiwara no Fuyutsugu, Fujiwara no Otsugu, Fujiwara no Sadatsugu, and Yoshimine Yasuyo to compile the text.
Three people, excluding the unfinished succession, died, so Emperor Junna later ordered Kiyohara Natsuno, Naoyuki O, Fujiwara Yoshino, Ono Minamori, Sakagami Imatsugu, and Shimada Kiyota to continue.
During the reign of Emperor Nimmyo, further decrees were issued to Fujiwara no Otsugu, Minamoto Tsunemoto, Fujiwara Yoshino, Fujiwara Yoshifusa, and Asakano Shitoru.
Furthermore, after adding Furutakaniwa and Yamada Furuetsugu, the completion was finally reported on December 9, 841 (January 5, 841).
The period it took to compile was 21 years, and the only person who was involved in the project spanning three emperors was Fujiwara no Suketsugu.
Following the "Nihon Shoki," this text records the reigns of Emperor Heijou, Emperor Saga, and Emperor Junna during the reign of Emperor Kanmu.

In the early 15th century, there were 40 volumes of the text, but they were later scattered. It was not until the disciple of Hani Ho Kichi, Inayama Yukinori, discovered a manuscript of 10 volumes at the Sanjo Nishi family (there is also a theory of the edited version by Yanagihara Norimitsu) that it was first published.
The existing volumes are volumes 5, 8, 12, 13 (Kammu), 14, 17 (Heijou), 20, 21, 22, 24 (Saga), totaling 10 volumes, with the reign of Emperor Junna completely missing.
It is possible to partially reconstruct the text from the excerpt version of the "Nihon Ki Ryaku" and the classification of the Six National Histories in the "Ruiju Kokushi".

There are "Nihon Isshi" and "Nihon Koki Ibun" which collect various excerpts from different places, based on which, the following Shueisha translated and annotated Japanese historical materials and the Kodansha Academic Bunko have been published.
It is said that the content most reflects the opinion of Fujiwara no Noritoshi.

Adding short biographies (obituaries) to the death articles of the Emperor and court officials is in line with the "Continuation of Japanese Chronicles," and is the same as other subsequent historical books.

However, the obituary in this book does not flow into one-sided, official praise or criticism, but rather contains many interesting descriptions with unique criticisms and impressions, making it unusual in the Six National Histories for maintaining a critical spirit.
It is known that the Rikkokushi contained a larger number of waka poems compared to earlier and later historical texts.
Sei Shonagon (around the third year of the Kocho era (966?) - around the second year of the Manju era (1025?)) was a female writer and poet of the Heian period.
There is a theory that her real name is Nagiko Kiyohara, but it is unknown.
One of the "Five Men of Pear Jar," she was the daughter of the renowned poet Kiyohara no Motosuke (908-990) in his later years.
There is an old tradition that identifies the mother as "Higaki no Ouna" in the "Gosen Wakashu," but this is nothing more than a wild and baseless theory.
My great-great-grandfather (some say great-grandfather) is the representative poet of the Kokin Wakashu, Kiyohara no Motosuke.
There are women who have become the wives of Gagaku leader Narinari, Dazai Shokan, Hana no Yama-in Denjo Hoshi Kaishu, and Fujiwara Norinari (the siblings of Fujiwara Michitsuna's mother).
"Sei Shonagon" is a pseudonym, with "Sei" taken from her family name Sei Genji and "Shonagon" taken from a court title of her relatives.
The real name is unknown, and there is a theory that it is "Nagiko" (from "Makura no Soshi Shou"), but it is not trustworthy.

She is counted as one of the thirty-six Immortal Poets of the Heian period, and her collection of 42 poems, "Kiyoshinagonshu" (the number of poems varies depending on the version, with 31 poems in the circulated version), has been passed down.
The "Goshūi Wakashū" includes 14 poems selected for imperial compilation.
Ashikaga Yoshiteru was the 15th shogun of the Muromachi shogunate and the last shogun of the Muromachi shogunate (reign: Eiroku 11 (1568) - Tensho 16 (1588)).
The father is Ashikaga Yoshiharu, the 12th shogun of the Muromachi shogunate.
The mother is the daughter of Konoe Hisamichi, Keijuin.
The 13th shogun, Ashikaga Yoshiteru, is a half-brother.
At first he was a monk, but when Yoshiteru was assassinated by Matsunaga Hisahide and others, he escaped from Kyoto with the help of Hosokawa Yusai and other vassals.
He was supported by Oda Nobunaga of Mino Province and went up to Kyoto, where he became the 15th shogun.
Eventually, he came into conflict with Nobunaga and, in conjunction with Takeda Shingen and Asakura Yoshikage, built a coalition to surround Nobunaga.
At one point, Nobunaga was cornered, but eventually he was expelled from Kyoto by Nobunaga, and the Muromachi shogunate was effectively destroyed.
After that, he spent his remaining years with the support of Motonari Mōri and then Toyotomi Hideyoshi.
He was born on November 13, 1537, as the second son of the 12th shogun, Ashikaga Yoshiharu.

Because there was a legitimate child of my older brother, Ashikaga Yoshiteru, I became the adopted child of my maternal grandfather, Konoe Hisatsugu, at a young age and entered the Buddhist priesthood (Kofukuji Ichijo-in) under the name Kakukei.
He later advanced to the position of Gonsyu Sotodzu at Kofukuji Temple.

In the Eiroku Incident of Eiroku 8 (1565), the 13th shogun, my brother Yoshiteru, was assassinated by Matsunaga Hisahide, the Sanjo Sanekata, and others, and my younger brother, Ashikaga Shusonin, who was the head of the Kano-in, was also lured to his death.

At this time, Yoshiaki was also captured by Matsunaga Hisahide and others, and imprisoned in Kofukuji Temple. (It is said that Hisahide and others feared turning Kofukuji Temple into an enemy by killing Yoshiaki, as Yoshiaki was the younger brother of the shogun and had been promised the position of head priest of Kofukuji Temple in the future).

However, with the help of vassals such as Hosokawa Yusai and Wada Koremasa, he managed to escape and on February 17, 1566, in the 9th year of the Eiroku era, he returned to secular life and took the name Yoshiaki.
In the book that recorded Yoshiaki's life, it is mentioned that he was also referred to as the "Warrior's Palace" and other aliases.
When he was expelled from Kyoto, he was attacked by night thieves and was also known as the "Poor Governor."
On April 21st, he was quietly promoted to Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade and appointed as Left Cavalry Captain.

There are opinions questioning the timing of the appointment, but according to Yamashina Genkitsu's "Genkitsu Kyo-ki", it is clear that he had already received the appointment before the day of the appointment of the shogun to Ashikaga Yoshihide, who was a rival to Yoshiaki, in February of the 11th year of Eiroku (1568). On the day of the shogun's appointment, a messenger from Yoshiaki appeared at Genkitsu's residence, who was the messenger of the appointment, asking for assistance in recommending his promotion to Jushi-shita, which caused confusion.

Yoshiaki, who escaped from Kyoto, initially relied on the father and son, Rokkaku Yoshiyoshi and Rokkaku Yoshiharu of Omi Province, but Yoshiharu secretly colluded with the Miyoshi Trio, so in August he fled to the domain of his sister's husband, Takeda Yoshitsugu in Wakasa Province.

However, the Wakasa Takeda clan did not have enough power to go up to the capital due to struggles for succession and power struggles among senior vassals. In September, they fled to Asakura Yoshikage in Echizen Province and requested assistance in restoring the shogunate.

However, Yoshikage Asakura already held the "Kuritani Gosho" branch of the Ashikaga Shogunate, including Ashikaga Tsugutomo, and did not have the intention of actively going up to the capital with the newly secularized Ashikaga Yoshiaki, so the journey to the capital did not materialize.

The role of Kanmuriyaku is being served by Asakura Yoshikage (Note that there is no official documentation or historical evidence that Yoshiteru had undergone the formal ceremony of Genpuku up to this point, making it an unusually late Genpuku for the time).
Eventually, with the mediation of Akechi Mitsuhide, a senior vassal of the Asakura family, he moved to Mino Province to seek the protection of Oda Nobunaga.
In September of the 11th year of Eiroku (1568), he was supported by Oda Nobunaga and went up to Kyoto.
On October 18th, he received the appointment as the 15th shogun from the Imperial Court.
At the same time, he was promoted to Jushi-i-no-jo (Junior Fourth Rank, Upper Grade) and appointed as Sangi (Councilor) and Left Guard Chūjō (Lieutenant General of the Left Division).

Enryaku-ji is a temple located in Sakamoto Honmachi, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture, and encompasses the entire Mount Hiei with an elevation of 848 meters.
Mount Hiei is often called by the name of Enryaku-ji Temple.
It was located north of Heian-kyo (Kyoto) and was also known as Hokurei.
It is the head temple of the Japanese Tendai sect, founded by the monk Saicho in the early Heian period (767-822).
The abbot (kanju) is called the Tendai Zasu and oversees the branch temples.
Since the founding of Kukai, it has been a center of Heian Buddhism alongside Mount Koya's Kongobuji Temple.

In addition to the teachings of the Tendai Lotus Sutra, esoteric Buddhism, Zen (meditation and insight), and chanting of the Buddha's name were also practiced, giving the appearance of a comprehensive Buddhist university. During the Heian period, it gained great power and received the respect of the imperial family and nobility.

In particular, the ritual prayers performed by esoteric Buddhism gathered support from the aristocracy of the Heian period, and the esoteric Buddhism of Enryaku-ji Temple competed for supremacy against the esoteric Buddhism of To-ji Temple (Tōmitsu) of the Shingon sect.

"Enryaku-ji" refers to the total of the three towers and sixteen valleys, such as the East Tower, West Tower, and Yokogawa, scattered in the precincts from the mountaintop of Mt. Hiei to the eastern foot.
In the 7th year of Enryaku (788), Saicho built a small hermitage called Ichijo Shikan-in, which was the beginning.
The temple name "Enryaku-ji," taken from the era name at its founding, was granted in the 14th year of the Kōnin era (824 AD) after the death of Saichō.

Enryaku-ji Temple has produced numerous famous monks, including Ennin, Enchin, the founder of the Yuzu Nenbutsu school Ryojin, the founder of the Jodo school Honen, the founder of the Jodo Shinshu school Shinran, the founder of the Rinzai school Eisai, the founder of the Soto school Dogen, the founder of the Nichiren school Nichiren, and many other prominent monks in Japanese Buddhist history. Because many founders of new Buddhist sects and famous monks in Japanese Buddhist history trained at Mount Hiei in their youth, it is also known as the "mother mountain of Japanese Buddhism."
Mount Hiei appears in many literary works.

In addition, rigorous ascetic practices such as the "12-year Mountain Retreat" and the "1000-day Pilgrimage" have been continued to the present day, and as a representative sacred site of Japanese Buddhism, it is also registered as a World Cultural Heritage Site by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

Mount Hiei is a mountain whose name is mentioned in the "Kojiki", and it is believed to have been a mountain of mountain worship since ancient times. At the Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine in Sakamoto at the eastern foot of the mountain, the deity Oyamazumi no Kami, the landlord deity of Mount Hiei, is enshrined.

Saicho's secular name was Mitsunobito Hirono, and he was born in the second year of Tenpyo Jingo (766) in Shiga District, Omi Province (Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture). (There is also a theory that he was born in 767).
At the age of 15, in the 11th year of the Hōki era (780), he received ordination (became a monk) under the guidance of the monk Gyōhyō at the Ōmi Kokubunji temple, and took the name Saichō.
At the age of 20, in the fourth year of Enryaku (785), I received ordination at Todai-ji Temple in Nara and became a formal monk.

The young Masumi, with his own thoughts, chose not to seek a stable position in the great temples of Nara, but instead secluded himself in Mount Hiei near his hometown, dedicating himself to training and studying scriptures.

Saicho considered the teachings of the Lotus Sutra to be the highest among the numerous scriptures, and he studied the "Three Great Works on the Lotus Sutra" by the Chinese Tiantai master Zhiyi, which include the "Mahayana Lotus Sutra Commentary," "Words and Phrases of the Lotus Sutra," and "Great Concentration and Insight."
In the 7th year of Enryaku (788), Saicho established a small temple called Ichijo Shikan-in at the current location of the Konpon Chudo, consisting of Yakushi-do, Monju-do, and Kyozo.
This temple is also called Mt. Hiei Temple, and the temple name "Enryaku-ji" with an era name was permitted after the death of Saicho in the 14th year of the Kōnin era (824).

During the reign of Emperor Kanmu, Saicho received the Emperor's support and the assistance of the Waki clan, who were close to the Emperor. As a result, Mount Hiei Temple gradually prospered as a dojo for national protection guarding the northeast of Kyoto.
In the 21st year of the Enryaku era (802 AD), Saicho was permitted to travel to Tang as a returning student (short-term overseas training student).
In the 23rd year of Enryaku (804 AD), I crossed over to Tang on a ship as part of a diplomatic mission.
Enchin studied Tendai teachings and Mahayana Bodhisattva precepts under the guidance of Doji and Ennin at the sacred site of Mount Hiei.
In addition, at the Longxing Temple in Yuezhou (Shaoxing), they are studying esoteric Buddhism from Shunxiao Ajari and Zen from Shakunen Zenji.
In the Kojiki and Nihon Shoki, it is said to have been created by Izanagi.
It is commonly believed that the moon is deified as a god who rules over the night, but there are also alternative theories (see below).
The reading of the name is also Tsukiyomi.
There is a story in the Nihon Shoki about the killing of Yasakatsumi, so although generally considered a male deity, there is no description in the Kojiki or Nihon Shoki that determines gender.

In the myths of other countries, the moon god is often depicted as a goddess, and there are also many goddesses with aggressive personalities in other countries' myths. Therefore, some scholars argue for the goddess theory, stating that the story of the killing of Hosokami by a male god cannot be definitively proven.
Tsukuyomi is considered the god of the moon, but there are various differences in his divinity depending on the literature.

In the Kojiki, it is said that Izanagi was born from his right eye when he escaped from Yomi and performed purification, and Amaterasu, born from his other eye, and Susanoo, born from his nose, together form the three noble children.

On the other hand, in the "Nihon Shoki," there is a story that Amaterasu was born from the left eye, contrary to the "Kojiki," and another story that she emerged from a white bronze mirror held in her right hand, with her dominion not limited to the heavens or the sea.
Tsukuyomi is born in opposition to Amaterasu, who symbolizes the sun, but in the field of comparative mythology, it is pointed out that similar ideas exist in various myths.

For example, in the Chinese legend of Pangu (as recorded in the "Book of History"), it is said that after Pangu died, his left eye became the sun and his right eye became the moon. Similarly, in Greek mythology, the sun god Apollo and the moon goddess Artemis are considered twins.
However, Apollo was originally a separate god from the sun god Helios, and it was not until later that the two were identified as the same.

In addition, in the Book of Genesis in the Old Testament, on the fourth day of creation, God created "two great lights" in the sky, namely the sun and the moon, to govern the day and night respectively, and to separate light from darkness. This is the creation of the sun and moon as described in the Bible.
The birth of Amaterasu and Tsukuyomi is also considered to follow the pattern of a common worldwide myth of the origin of the sun and moon as a pair.

In Japanese mythology, Tsukuyomi is considered an important god alongside Amaterasu and Susanoo, but he does not appear much in the myths of the Kojiki and Nihon Shoki, and is generally lacking in activity.
It is only briefly mentioned in the Nihon Shoki, Book Five, Chapter Eleven, that the origin of grains is discussed.
There is a theory that balance is maintained by placing a god who does nothing between the contrasting personalities of Amaterasu and Susanoo.
A similar structure can also be seen in the relationship between Amaterasu and Takamimusubi, as well as between Hoori (Yamasachihiko) and Hoderi (Umisachihiko).
This is called the hollow structure of Japanese mythology.
Some argue that Susano'o and Susanoo are the same deity due to overlapping domains and episodes.
In the first volume of the Kojiki, he was born when Izanagi washed his right eye and is called one of the "three noble children" along with Amaterasu and Susanoo.
Tsukuyomi is ordered to "inform the night-eating country," but there is no further activity after this.
There is also a theory that it is the country of Yomimi, where the god Izanami is.

In the fifth section of the Age of the Gods in the Nihon Shoki, it is briefly stated in the text that "a god of the moon, shining brightly after the sun, was born and sent to the heavens to rule alongside the sun." However, in the following first book, there is a different account where Izanagi no Mikoto gave birth to Oho-namuchi no Mikoto while holding a white bronze mirror in his left hand, and gave birth to Tsukiyomi no Mikoto while holding a white bronze mirror in his right hand.

There are several stories about being instructed to rule the heavens alongside Amaterasu-Omikami in the domain of domination, while there is also a story of being commanded to control the eight hundred layers of the tides of the Cang Hai Yuan (this seems to have come from the idea that the moon controls the tides), and multiple stories of the birth of three gods are parallel.

In the fifth section of the Kojiki, it is said that Amaterasu-Omikami and Tsukuyomi-no-Mikoto were both ordered to rule the heavens together. However, later Tsukuyomi-no-Mikoto was commanded to descend from the heavens to meet with the god of food, Ukemochi, who had been sent by Amaterasu.
In response, the god of food and agriculture spat out rice as an offering, but Tsukuyomi no Mikoto was disgusted and angry, so he killed the god of food and agriculture with a sword.
From the corpse of the food god, cows, horses, silkworms, rice, and other things were born, and this became the origin of grains.
Onmyoji (onmyoji, onyoji) is one of the official positions belonging to the Onmyoryo of the Nakatsukasasho under the Ritsuryo system in ancient Japan.

It refers to the position of a skilled official (technician) who performs divination, geomancy, and other tasks based on the Yin-Yang Five Elements philosophy, and is later responsible for overseeing divination, sorcery, and all aspects of rituals beyond the original Ritsuryo regulations.

Since the Middle Ages, it has come to refer mainly to non-official individuals who practice divination, sorcery, and rituals privately in various places, and in modern times it is defined as a type of clergy who perform private prayers and divination in the private sector.
It is sometimes pronounced as "onyoji" without linking sounds.

It is believed that all phenomena are based on the combination of Yin-Yang and Five Elements ideology, which began in ancient China during the Xia and Shang dynasties and was almost completed during the Zhou dynasty. Astronomy, calendars, divination, and timekeeping, which are closely related to this ideology, were transmitted directly from mainland China (Han and Sui dynasties) or through the western regions of the Korean Peninsula (Goguryeo and Baekje) to Japan by the Asuka period in the 5th to 6th centuries, at the latest by the arrival of the Five Classics scholars from Baekje in 512 (Emperor Keitai's 7th year) or the arrival of the Yi scholars in 554 (Emperor Kinmei's 15th year).

Initially, the influence of these various studies on politics and culture was minimal, but in 602 AD (the 10th year of Empress Suiko), Kanroku, who can be called a pioneer of Onmyodo in Japan, came from Baekje and began teaching various studies to 34 selected bureaucrats, including Prince Shotoku, which began to have a significant impact on our country's politics.

For the first time in Japan, the calendar (Genka calendar) was adopted as the official calendar, and in order to absorb Buddhist teachings, Yin-Yang Five Elements philosophy, and calendar methods, an envoy was sent to Sui, an advanced civilization country, in 607 (15th year of Empress Suiko). The influence of Yin-Yang Five Elements philosophy became prominent in the establishment of Prince Shotoku's Seventeen-Article Constitution and the Twelve-Level Cap and Rank System.

After that, the imperial court continued to send exchange students with the Sui Dynasty (later with the Tang Dynasty), and also invited many monks or scholars from the western coast of the Korean Peninsula or mainland China to further absorb knowledge.

As the introduction of various studies progresses, it has become important in Japan to consider the movements and positions of the sun, moon, stars, and planets, and to predict the future by judging good and bad luck based on the principles of the Five Elements generating and overcoming each other, in order to obtain guidance for various matters and determine actions. As a strategy to judge good and bad luck and obtain a code of conduct, the Yin-Yang and Five Elements philosophy has come to be emphasized.

In the 7th century, Emperor Tenmu, who was a master of astrology and had a deep understanding of Yin-Yang and Five Elements philosophy, took a divination rod during the Jinshin War and established the "Onmyoryo" and Japan's first observatory in 676 (the 4th year of Emperor Tenmu's reign).

In the year 685 (13th year of the Tenmu Emperor), the term "Onmyoji" began to be used, and the Yin-Yang Five Elements ideology became even more popular. In the Yoro Ritsuryo of 718, the establishment of the Onmyo-ryo as a bureau within the Nakatsukasa-sho was formalized, with the appointment of permanent officials such as astronomers, onmyoji, calendar experts, and timekeepers. Alongside the Kiboku of the Jingikan, they were responsible for conducting official divination.

Those responsible for the technology brought from the continent are typically individuals skilled in that field. Therefore, various scholars and onmyoji are appointed with expertise in various disciplines and proficiency in reading Chinese texts. These individuals are often immigrants from mainland China, who have held hegemony over the continent in the past such as the Former Han, Later Han, and Sui dynasties, as well as the Goguryeo and Baekje kingdoms on the western coast of the Korean Peninsula, and occasionally scholars who originally came from Silla, which was a power on the eastern coast of the Korean Peninsula.

In particular, following the defeat in the Battle of Baekgang in 663 AD (2nd year of Tenji), where Japan sent reinforcements to its close ally Baekje, Silla unified the Korean Peninsula after the downfall of the Baekje dynasty. Many scholars from Baekje sought refuge and immigrated, with a large number of them being appointed to official positions.

The original techniques of the Onmyoryo at the time of its establishment were purely divination, feng shui (similar to what is now called "geomancy"), astronomical observation, astrology, calendar creation, determination of auspicious and inauspicious days, and timekeeping. Therefore, they mainly predicted astronomical observations, calendar management, and the auspiciousness of events based on theoretical analysis according to the principles of Yin and Yang, without performing any religious rituals or sorcery like Shinto priests or monks. However, they played an important role in selecting auspicious days for construction projects at the imperial court and in determining the auspiciousness of locations and directions during events such as the relocation of the capital.
